author: jessie scanlon
text: the pressure is on at the new $287 million b factory, a demolition derby for physicists. the stanford linear accelerator center's particle collider brings electrons and their antimatter counterparts, positrons, into a head-on collision in order to produce b meson particles. the new collider's key feature is an electron beam three times stronger than its positron counterpart. when the b factory hits full speed later this year, it will be churning out some 30 million b mesons annually. slac is racing against a competing facility in japan to produce the tens of millions of these heavy subatomic particles that scientists believe can help explain the difference between matter and antimatter. to what end? "we can't rerun the big bang in our laboratory," explains slac physicist michael riordan. "but in all of these atom smashers around the world, we can simulate parts of that event."electric wordbody shopgod of thundersim bangepinion makersluminarypower trip
